Education Secretary Michael Gove said: Under the last government thousands of great people left the teaching profession because behaviour was out of control and they were forced to spend far too much time on paperwork. That's why we're taking action to restore discipline and reduce bureaucracy. Teachers will be free to impose the penalties they need to keep order, and free from the red tape which swallows up teaching time, so they can get on with their first duty- raising standards. over as CEO Google announced Thursday that co-founder Larry Page would replace Eric Schmidt as chief executive of the Internet giant in April. Google said Eric Schmidt would remain with the company as executive chairman and focus on deals, partnerships, customers and broader business relationships. The firm's other co-founder, Sergey Brin , will work on strategic projects and new products, Google said in a statement. It said the management changes would take effect on April 4.

2009. The dispute over Mirafiori is also part of a wider struggle by the outspoken Sergio Marchionne to bring about radical reforms in Italian industry. In October, he ignited controversy when he said that Fiat would be better off if it eliminated Italy. Italy ranks 118th out of 139 countries in work efficiency and is 48th in industrial competitiveness. "Not a cent from the two billion euros of profits forecast for 2010 will be generated in Italy, he said, pointing out that Fiat's 6,100 workers in Poland produce the same number of cars as the company's 22,000 auto workers in Italy.
